title: Source: Ausonius, Moselle

note: Constantine modified the coin, creating the Solidus.
title: Aureus: Roman gold coin originally worth 25 denarii or silver coins. Under Diocletian, 60 aurei were in a pound of gold

Donatist: A follower to a group in North Africa which argued for harsh penalties for Christians who handed over (traditors) sacred books. Equestrian: The business class in republican Rome, during the Roman Empire also became part of the imperial bureaucracy
The region of modern-day France, Low Countries, western Germany, and northwest Switzerland. Gnosticism: A sect which claimed to posses “special knowledge” of salvation
Holy Roman Empire: The title of Charlemagne’s empire created in 800 c.e
Patrician: A Roman aristocrat, a member of a privileged class. Plebeian: The common people
Theurgy: The intervention of the divine or supernatural in the lives of humans which Neo-Platonists believed was usually achieved through beneficent magic
The Abinnaeus Archive: Papers of a Roman Officer in the Reign of Constantius II
One of the numerous archives recovered from Egyptian papyri deals with a low-level military administrator and his dealings with officials and local individuals
The Acts of the Christian Martyrs
A collection of authentic acts translated, an important source for early hagiography and Diocletian’s persecutions

note: This translation is abridged.
title: The Later Roman Empire
The last great Latin historian details the careers of Constantius II
Although incomplete, his work is important for understanding the military disasters of Julian and Valens

note: Many of the earliest Christian texts are translated, including some of the more obscure ones.
title: Ammianus Marcellinus
The entire surviving work is translated. Ante-Nicene Christian Library: Translations of the Writings of the Fathers down to A.D. 325
The Case Against the Pagans
Arnobius was a fourthcentury convert and apologist; his work provides a good example of the arguments used by learned converts who were not trained as theologians
The City of God
The Christian theologian refutes the pagan view that Christianity caused Rome’s fall
Confessions
A classic work, detailing his journey to Christianity. Cassiodorus. The Letters of Cassiodorus, being a Condensed Translation of the Variae epistolae of Magnus Aurelius Cassiodorus Senator

A collection of letters from a bureaucrat describing life in Roman Italy after 476; they are important for showing that the institutions and concepts of Roman life continued even after the last emperor had been deposed
The Variae of Magnus Aurelius Cassiodorus Senator being Documents of the Kingdom of the Ostrogoths in Italy Cassiodorus, Senator; Theodoric, King of the Ostrogoths
The various works are concerned with the new post-Roman government of Theodoric
The Chronicle of John, Bishop of Nikiu
A vivid Christian account drawn mainly from the Egyptian point of view, but often unreliable

note: Although not always reliable, it does provide useful information on popularly held ideas.
title: The Chronicle of Joshua the Stylite

Work describing the city of Edessa and the East during the Late Roman period by one of its own citizens. Chronicon Paschale 284–628 AD. Translated with notes and introduction by Michael Whitby and Mary Whitby
Work detailing the history of Western Christianity during the fourth and fifth centuries
Including the Twelve Tables, the Institutes of Gaius, the Rules of Ulpian, the Opinions of Paulus, the Enactments of Justinian, and the Constitutions of Leo

note: the translation is flawed, however. Is also available online at:
title: Translation of civil laws from Justinian’s code, this is important for showing the evolution of legal ideas during the late empire
The History of the Church from Christ to Constantine
with a new introduction by Andrew Annotated Bibliography 169 Louth
An official account of Christianity written after its acceptance during the reign of Constantine, this ancient history provides the most detailed story of Christianity
In Praise of Constantine: A Historical Study and New Translation of Eusebius’ Tricennial Orations
A Panegyric written near the end of Constantine’s life, provides a good source for the official view of Constantine’s accomplishments

note: General history down to Valens provides information often ignored by Christian historians or missing from Ammianus.
title: Life of Constantine, Introduction

Eusebius’ account is often flawed since he views Constantine as the Christian protector. Eutropius. The Breviarium ab Urbe Condita of Eutropius: The Right Honourable Secretary of State for General Petitions: Dedicated to Lord Valens, Gothicus Maximus & Perpetual Emperor
The Letters of St
Important letters from a Church Father deals with all aspects of life and religion during the fourth and fifth centuries

author.literal: Johnson, Allan Chester, Paul Robinson Coleman-Norton, [and] Frank Card Bourne.

note: Includes the works: The Wrath of God, The Death of the Persecutors, and The Phoenix, arguing against paganism.
title: Ancient Roman Statutes: a Translation, with Introduction, Commentary, Glossary, and Index

A collection of ancient laws from Greece and Rome provides a representative sampling dealing with economic, political, social, and military aspects. Jordanes. The Gothic History of Jordanes in English Version
Pro-Gothic account by a Romanized Goth presents information differing from Roman accounts

translator.given: Lactantius Minor Works Sister Mary Francis

author.literal: Johnson, Allan Chester, Paul Robinson Coleman-Norton, [and] Frank Card Bourne.

title: The Works of Lactantius
Works from the Latin rhetorician and court instructor that justify, defend, and articulate the case for Christianity

container-title: Praise of Later Roman Emperors: The Panegyrici Latini: Introduction, Translation, and Historical Commentary, with the Latin Text of R.A.B. Mynors
The Theodosian Code and Novels, and the Sirmondian Constitutions
note: Excellent translation of Rome’s other great legal code dealing with the enactments after Diocletian to Theodosius II. Victor, Sextus Aurelius Liber de Caesaribus.
title: Syrus Saint
Collection of important sources shows various views in favor of and opposed
Readings in Late Antiquity: A Sourcebook
Good collection of various sources on all aspects of ancient life

Important collection of Latin Gallic panegyrics details the history and official imperial view of emperors, especially for the First and Second Tetrarchy. Orosius, Paulus. The Seven Books of History Against the Pagans
Late Roman history account from a Christian defends Christianity from the pagan charge that the new religion destroyed Rome

On the Government of God; A Treatise Where in Are Shown by Argument and by Examples Drawn from the Abandoned Society of the Times the Ways of God Toward His Creatures. Indited by Salvian as a Warning and Counsel
Late Roman account from a Christian arguing that the end of Rome came from the corrupt government

Loeb Classical Library. Work detailing the life of the late fourth century Gaul, provides examples of all aspects of life and politics. Themistius. Politics, Philosophy, and Empire in the Fourth Century: Select Orations of Themistius
Works addressed to Eastern Emperors of fourth century comparing them to Plato’s idea of the just king

A collection of imperial biographies beginning with Augustus down to the end of the fourth century; he is im-Annotated Bibliography 171 portant for the later period before Constantine where literary sources are lacking

note: blamed Christianity, especially Constantine, for Rome’s fall.
title: New History
Byzantine pagan author writing down to the fifth century
The Villa: Form and Ideology of Country Houses
A general work discusses the villa from antiquity to the twentieth century
Roman Building: Materials and Techniques
This thorough technical work discusses all aspects of building, and is an excellent starting point in any research on Late Roman architecture and construction
A Conflict of Ideas in the Late Roman Empire: The Clash between the Senate and Valentinian I
An important work, discusses post-Constantinian politics between a Christian emperor and pagan senate
Banking and Business in the Roman World
A description of the history of finances focused mainly during the late republic and early empire
Cruelty and Civilization: The Roman Games
The work presents a complete examination and history of the Roman games: gladiators, hunts, and races; is a good introductory work
Constantine the Great and the Christian Revolution
A standard work on the life of Constantine portrays him in a balanced light
Ammianus Marcellinus and the Representation of Historical Reality
Barnes provides a thorough reexamination and evaluation of Ammianus, challenging many of the traditional views of scholarship. This should be the starting point for any analysis of Ammianus

note: The work is as much a history/biography of Athanasius as Constantius.
title: Athanasius and Constantius: Theology and Politics in the Constantinian Empire
The author attempts to place Athanasius in the broader context of the Roman Empire 172 Annotated Bibliography under Constantius II
Constantine and Eusebius
Scholarly work covers the reign of Constantine and the influence of Eusebius on Constantine’s image
The New Empire of Diocletian and Constantine
Excellent source work examining various components of the imperial court, individuals, military actions, and imperial journeys
Roman Domestic Buildings
Describes the different types of private buildings
East Roman Foreign Policy: Formation and Conduct from Diocletian to Anastasius
Work describes the relationship between Rome and the Sassanids focusing on the military and diplomatic acts
The Age of Constantine and Julian
Provides a general history of the fourth century focusing on Constantine’s new Christian empire and Julian’s reaction; presents Constantine as a sincere Christian

note: Standard scholarly work on Julian focuses on his career and his impact.
title: Julian the Apostate
Augustine of Hippo: A Biography
Excellent biography of the great Christian writer describes not only his life but his environment
The Making of Late Antiquity
Good general account of the political, social, and cultural world of the Mediterranean from 400–700 c.e
Society and the Holy in Late Antiquity
Discusses the interaction between the new state religion Christianity and society
The Age of Constantine the Great
Classic account of Constantine describes how he created the new Christian empire
Barbarians within the Gates of Rome: A Study of Roman Military Policy and the Barbarians, ca. 375–425 A.D
Attempt to place the military picture of the late Roman Empire in perspective
History of the Later Roman Empire from the Death of Theodosius I to the Death of Justinian
Standard reference work on the fifth century provides a useful historical description of the Germanic invaders

note: General work on the fourth century provides an excellent overview of the Constantinian emperors.
title: Circus Factions: Blues and Greens at Rome and Byzantium
Scholarly work examines the social, political, military, religious, and imperial history of the games
The Later Roman Empire, A.D
Carausius and Allectus: The British Usurpers
Author presents a thorough examination of the British separatist movement during Diocletian’s reign, especially useful for the numismatic evidence
The Fall of Rome; Can It Be Explained?
The volume gives a collection of extracts from modern scholars examining the various reasons for Rome’s fall. The work provides a good introduction to the various modern theories
Frontier and Society in Roman North Africa
The work provides an examination of Roman influence before the fourth century. The work is a good starting place in attempting to understand the world of the Donatist movement
Women in Late Antiquity: Pagan and Christian Lifestyles
Presents an overview of women’s personal lives and how law, morality, and religious concerns affected their lives
Unit Sizes in the Late Roman Army
An examination of the Late Roman army as it pertains to the Notitia Dignitatum

container-title: Downey, Glanville. Antioch in the Age of Theodosius the Great
note: Excellent work on the topography, social setting, and history of Antioch, one of Rome’s most important cities in the East.
title: The Ancient City: Life in Classical Athens and Rome

Popular book on the city 174 Annotated Bibliography of Rome provides animated illustrations on ancient buildings and daily life. Corcoran, Simon. The Empire of the Tetrarchs: Imperial Pronouncements and Government, A.D
Scholarly work on the legal documents of Diocletian, which provide a justification for the Tetrarch’s rule
The Making of a Christian Empire: Lactantius and Rome
Examines Lactantius’ influence on Constantine and his government
Constantinople in the Age of Justinian
Presents the city of Constantinople as it appeared at the end of the fifth century
The Life and Times of St. Ambrose
Describes Roman society during the late fourth century and Ambrose’s impact on Roman history. Duncan-Jones, Richard. The Economy of the Roman Empire: Quantitative Studies
The author provides evidence and rationale for the use of statistics to understand imperial Roman society
Imperial Rome and Christian Triumph: the Art of the Roman Empire A.D
Excellent work detailing the fusion of Roman and Christian ideologies seen in art
Bathing in Public in the Roman World
Modern work detailing the importance of the bath complex in Roman society
Pagans and Christians
Describes the social and cultural world of Christian and pagan struggles, easily readable
Roman Women
The work has chapters on individual Roman women from the late republic to the end of the empire
The Rise of Christianity
Standard work describes the growth of Christianity and its position in the Annotated Bibliography 175
The author describes the various problems facing Christianity during its early period
The Roman Empire: Economy, Society, and Culture
Describes their interaction, especially by using archaeological material to provide new models and directions
The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire
This classic work provides a starting point for all further work on the Late Roman period
The Age of Attila; Fifth-century Byzantium and the Barbarians
Places Attila in the context of fifth-century Rome and his importance in Eastern relations
The Army of the Caesars
A general introductory discussion of the early imperial army provides some useful background information on the struggle between the army and the emperors
The Collapse and Recovery of the Roman Empire
The work is a good introduction and popular account of the third century and its crisis
Constantine the Great: The Man and His Times
A general biography of Constantine and his career, geared for the general reader
From Rome to Byzantium: The Fifth Century A.D
A general description of the collapse of the Roman West and the predominance of the East
From Croesus to Constantine: The Cities of Western Asia Minor and Their Arts in Greek and Roman Times
This work provides an overview of the development of the cities of modern-day Turkey with their archaeological and monumental materials

note: Cyprian, Lactantius, Ambrose, Jerome, Augustine, and Boethius.
title: The Fathers of the Latin Church
Gives the careers and dis-176 Annotated Bibliography cusses the works of the Latin Fathers Tertullian

author.literal: Harl, Kenneth W. Coinage in the Roman Economy, 300 B.C. to A.D.

note: An excellent scholarly work on Sidonius and fifth-century Gaul, this volume provides the biographical and historical background for his voluminous letters.
title: An attempt to place coinage in the wider political system of the Roman world; shows the interaction of coinage, the government, and society

note: laws, Christianity in the code, and the code’s later history.
title: The Theodosian Code
A collection of articles by experts focusing on different aspects of the code, such as its background, sources, Licinius
Good examination of the interaction between the Goths and Rome and their entry into the Roman Empire
Theodoric the Goth, the Barbarian Champion of Civilization
Standard work on post-476 Rome describes the new kingdom of the Goths
Roman Circuses: Arenas for Chariot Racing
The work provides a thorough review of the archaeological sites and the remains of the circuses in the Roman world, and includes copious pictures illustrating the sites
The Limits of Empire: The Roman Army in the East
Author provides a detailed survey of the Eastern provinces of the empire, and the problems along the imperial frontier
The Franks
A good introduction to the history of the Franks before and after the fall of the West, concentrates mainly on Clovis and his creation of the Frankish monarchy
The Decline of the Ancient World
Jones gives a popular version of his Later
The Later Roman Empire, 284–602: A Social Economic and Administrative Survey
Excellent standard scholarly work from which all modern studies stem
The Roman Economy: Studies in Ancient Economic and Administrative History
A collection of his important articles collected and reprinted, allowing for detailed analysis of different aspects of Late Roman society

note: theories for Rome’s fall.
title: Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire: Why Did It Collapse?
Gives short excerpts of various modern scholars

note: Work provides an excellent physical overview of the Christian city of Rome.
title: The Emperor Theodosius and the Establishment of Christianity
General work on the rule of Theodosius and his role in making Christianity the official state religion
Profile of a City, 312–1308
Rome in Late Antiquity: Everyday Life and Urban Change, A.D
Author gives an excellent introduction and description of the various components of the city of Rome; this is a good starting place for examining the city
The Kingdom of the Franks: North-west Europe before Charlemagne
General introduction to the art, history, and archaeology of the Franks, geared to the general audience
Failure of Empire: Valens and the Roman State in the Fourth Century A.D
Scholarly work on the rule of Valens leading to the disaster at Adrianople
From Diocletian to the Arab Conquest: Change in the Late Roman Empire
A series of articles addressing various subjects relating to the Late Roman world
Art Forms and Civic Life in the Late Roman Empire
Traces the changes in art during the Late Roman period; argues for a fundamental shift away from Rome toward the provinces
The Grand Strategy of the Roman Empire from the First Century A.D. to the Third
Describes the changes in imperial military strategy and how it changed during the crises of the third century, arguing for an imperial planning of the defense in depth

container-title: MacMullen, Ramsay. Christianity and Paganism in the Fourth to Eighth Centuries
title: Art and Ceremony in Late Antiquity
Discusses the various imperial ceremonies as seen in art and how they relate to creation of a more formal court ceremony
Shows that Christianity did not become universal with the Constantinian age, but rather the struggle between the two continued
Constantine
The author gives a good general biography of the emperor; geared for introductory study
Corruption and the Decline of Rome
Author argues that late Rome became more oppressive and regimented

note: Work provides a thorough examination of the Huns, exploring all aspects of their society, history, religion, art, and economy.
title: Soldier and Civilian in the Later Roman Empire
Work describes the interaction and struggle between the military and civilians during the post-Diocletianic period
The World of the Huns: Studies in Their History and Culture
The End of Ancient Christianity
Examines the forces that changed the Christian world from the fourth through the sixth centuries
The Roman Empire of Ammianus
Exhaustive, seminal, and scholarly work on all aspects of Ammianus; describes the Roman Empire during his time

Scholarly work detailing the history and personalities of the Valentianian and Theodosian regimes. The work is an excellent starting point in understanding the position of pagan and Christian senators and their interaction with the emperors and each other

note: Annotated Bibliography 179
Houses, Villas, and Palaces in the Roman World.
title: Christianity in the Roman Empire
Author provides a good introduction to the rise of Christianity in the Roman Empire for the general reader
An excellent examination of the various forms of Roman structures in the different regions of the empire
The Roman Near East, 31 B.C.–A.D. 337
Provides a comprehensive discussion of the East during the early empire; is especially useful in assembling the various source materials for the military reorganization by Diocletian and Constantine
Theodoric in Italy
Scholarly work gives the career of Theodoric in fifth–sixth-century Italy
Twilight of Empire: The Roman Army from the Reign of Diocletian until the Battle of Adrianople
A description of the Late Roman army focuses on the reforms made by Constantine toward the creation of the mobile armies
Cassiodorus
A thorough scholarly study of the life and works of Cassiodorus; discusses not only his background but his interactions with Theodoric and his writings
The Library of Lactantius
A standard work describes the life, influence, and writing of Lactantius
Galla Placidia Augusta
Author presents a balanced biography of the imperial woman who attempted to bring about a union between Rome and the Visigoths
Rome: Its People, Life and Customs
A good popular discussion of everyday life in Rome during the empire, this volume is geared to the general audience

note: reprinted, with corrections]. The starting point for further studies on the imperial army; although mainly concerned with the pre-Diocletianic army, provides useful information on the makeup of the legions.
title: The Roman Legions
The Excellent Empire: The Fall of Rome and the Triumph of the Church
The author discusses the work of Gibbon and the impact Christian writers had on Gibbon’s view of history
Layers of Loyalty in Latin Panegyric, A.D
A scholarly discussion of the Latin speeches made during Diocletian’s and Constantine’s reign, placing them in the historical context of imperial patronage
Julian the Apostate
Popular biography of Julian attempts to place him within his struggles with Christianity
The Roman Villa in Britain
Standard work on the rise and development of villas in England provides a good introduction to the various stages in British development
Landowners and Tenants in Roman Egypt: The Social Relations of Agriculture in the Oxyrhynchite Nome
A systematic study of landed estates describes their interaction with the countryside using papyri
The Episode of Carausius and Allectus: The Literary and Numismatic Evidence
A detailed description of the primary sources, literary, archaeological, and numismatic, surrounding Carausius and Allectus

note: Scholarly work describes Arnobius’ position in Christian apologists and Diocletian’s response to Christianity.
title: Arnobius of Sicca: Religious Conflict and Competition in the Age of Diocletian
The Roman Empire from Severus to Constantine
General history of third century, focuses mainly on the early period and its collapse
The Late Roman Army
An excellent overview of the Late Roman army, especially its units and their functions, the work is useful in showing the changes that occurred due to the Germanic invasions
Roman Art
Standard introduction gives a good overview to the various forms of art
Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World, and Mapby-Map Directory
An excellent, up-to-date atlas; a must for locating the various sites
The Huns
A thorough examination of the Huns, their history and society, this work focuses mainly on the political and military exploits of Attila
Romans and Barbarians: The Decline of the Western Empire

A reprint of a series of scholarly articles, together with added sections, discusses the fifth-century Germanic settlements and their aftermath. The chapters deal with Gaul, Italy, Noricum, and Spain, providing detailed information and analysis of the end of Roman rule and the rise of Germanic power in each area
Themistius and the Imperial Court: Oratory, Civic Duty, and Paideia from Constantius to Theodosius. Ann Arbor

Provides a reassessment of Themistius’ life and works within the framework of the fourth-century oratory at Constantinople. The author argues for a new interpretation showing that Themistius is not a flatterer out for personal gain, but rather a leader and orator of Constantinople
The Decline of Rome
The author describes the collapse of Rome, presenting the cultural and social changes which occurred during the fourth century
Doctors and Councils
A series of lectures covers the lives of Greek and Latin Fathers along with the four main councils in the East against Arius
The North African Provinces from Diocletian to the Vandal Conquest
Excellent work describes the African provinces and their organizations during the fourth and fifth centuries
Diocletian and the Roman Recovery
A general popular account of Diocletian and his reign
Theodosius: The Empire at Bay
A detailed and comprehensive summary of the emperor’s life and his policies, especially on Theodosius’ treatment of Christianity
Discusses and describes the great villa in Sicily; attempts to answer the question of whom it was built for or by
